title: Bakwara
text:
Bakwara is a village in <a href="Rahi%2C%20Raebareli">Rahi</a> block of <a href="Rae%20Bareli%20district">Rae Bareli district</a>, <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is located 15 km from <a href="Rae%20Bareli">Rae Bareli</a>, the district headquarters. As of 2011, it has a total population of 1,540 people, in 257 households. It has one primary school and no medical facilities and it hosts a weekly <a href="haat">haat</a> but not a permanent market. It belongs to the <a href="nyaya%20panchayat">nyaya panchayat</a> of <a href="Rustampur">Rustampur</a>.
The <a href="1951%20Census%20of%20India">1951 census</a> recorded Bakwara as comprising 4 hamlets, with a total population of 558 people (305 male and 253 female), in 106 households and 106 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 470 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. 16 residents were literate, 8 male and 8 female. The village was listed as belonging to the <a href="pargana">pargana</a> of Rae Bareli North and the <a href="thana">thana</a> of <a href="Nasirabad%2C%20Raebareli">Nasirabad</a>.
The <a href="1961%20Census%20of%20India">1961 census</a> recorded Bakwara as comprising 4 hamlets, with a total population of 573 people (294 male and 279 female), in 124 households and 120 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 470 <a href="acre">acre</a>s.
The <a href="1981%20Census%20of%20India">1981 census</a> recorded Bakwara as having a population of 821 people, in 155 households, and having an area of 192.64 <a href="hectare">hectare</a>s. The main staple foods were listed as wheat and rice.
The <a href="1991%20Census%20of%20India">1991 census</a> recorded Bakwara as having a total population of 1,089 people (534 male and 555 female), in 196 households and 190 physical houses. The area of the village was listed as 197 hectares. Members of the 0-6 age group numbered 255, or 23% of the total; this group was 51% male (129) and 49% female (126). Members of <a href="scheduled%20caste">scheduled caste</a>s numbered 149, or 14% of the village's total population, while no members of <a href="scheduled%20tribes">scheduled tribes</a> were recorded. The <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> of the village was 28% (238 men and 68 women). 296 people were classified as main workers (260 men and 36 women), while 189 people were classified as marginal workers (5 men and 184 women); the remaining 604 residents were non-workers. The breakdown of main workers by employment category was as follows: 182 cultivators (i.e. people who owned or leased their own land); 58 agricultural labourers (i.e. people who worked someone else's land in return for payment); 1 worker in livestock, forestry, fishing, hunting, plantations, orchards, etc.; 0 in mining and quarrying; 0 household industry workers; 28 workers employed in other <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a>, processing, service, and repair roles; 2 <a href="construction%20worker">construction worker</a>s; 7 employed in trade and commerce; 0 employed in transport, storage, and communications; and 18 in other services.
